question.name: 43.1.5.2 Regression Curves - Quadratic
question.questiontext:
Regression Curves - the Quadratic Case

We are looking for a functional relation of the form \[ y = \alpha + \beta x+ \gamma x^2 , \] and so, using the method of least squares, we require the values of \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\_ which minimize the expression \[ f(a,b,c) = \sum_{r=1}^n \left( y_r - a - bx_r - cx_r^2 \right)^2 . \] Note here that the regression described by the form \[ y = \alpha + \beta x + \gamma x^2 \] is actually a linear regression since the expression is linear in \(\alpha\), \(\beta\) and \(\gamma\). Omitting the subscripts and using partial differentiation gives \[ \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial a} = -2 \sum \left( y - a - bx -cx^2 \right)\] \[ \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial b} = -2 \sum x \left( y - a - bx -cx^2 \right)\] \[ \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial c} = -2 \sum x^2 \left( y - a - bx -cx^2 \right)\] At a minimum we require \[ \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial a} = \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial b} = \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial c}= 0, \] which results in the three linear equations \[ \sum y - na -b\sum x - c\sum x^2 = 0\] \[ \sum xy - a\sum x -b \sum x^2 - c \sum x^3 = 0\] \[ \sum x^2 y - a\sum x^2 - b \sum x^3 - c\sum x^4 = 0\] which can be solved to give the values of \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\).
